body.p: To His Excellency

Thos E Bramlette Govener of the State of Kentucky; Your Petitioner would respectfully represent; that on the day of 1863; He became the Bail of one Frank Yocum for the appearance of said Yocum at the October Term of the Jefferson Circuit Court; to answer two indictments for the Larceny of two old-trunks: ^and some articles of womens apparel^ said to have been stolen from Eleonora Hill; and Sarah Bell: each of whom are notorious prostitutes; and Keepers of houses of prostitution in the City of Louisville: That at the calling of the two cases: the said Defendant Yocum failed to answer, and a forfeiture of your petitioners Bonds for $400.00 ^in^ each ^case^ was taken in favor of the State of Kentucky ^on the 19th day of October 1863^. Your Petitioner could not produce said Yocum in Court; Because he was at that time, on his way back to or in his native country of Germany where He is now as your Petitioner is informed and believes; Your Petitioner, says that He is informed and believes that from the threats and conduct of the prosecuting witnesses and their hangers-on said Yocum became alarmed and fled the country:

Your Petitioner says that Yocum has lived in
and about this city for several years and his occupation was that of a Cultivater of flowers He attended to flowers and shrubbery in the grounds that surrounded the houses of Several of our Citizens: and made the impression that He was an honest hearted and simple minded man. his wife for a long time sold flowers in the market, and your petitioner had made her acquaintance, most favorably, and by her entreaties and tears: He was induced to become the Bail of her husband the said Frank Yocum: not believeing him guilty of the charges made against him by the women mentioned a bove; nor does your petitioner believe now that He was guilty: but by reason of his being a simple and ignorant ^man^ He was scared away, when he considered the miserable characters of those who were prosecuting him, and were the witnesses against him:

Your Petitioner says, that He is not able to to state to pay the state these heavy amounts; and He submits to your Excellency to remit to him the said forfeitures; which are is grievous and ruinous to him; and the loss of which to the public: (which your petitioner has served long and laboriously, without adequate compensation) will not, feel: -- The premises considered He prays your Excellency to interpose the Executive clemency in his behalf: and save him from this unforseen and luckless misfortune
except as to the clerks and Sheriffs fees and the fees to the Commonwealths Attorney

Your Obt Servant
E. S. Craig
E. S. Craig states that the facts stated of his own knowledge, in the above petition are true; and those stated from information He believes to be true
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 5th day of December 1863
Jos Clement Justice of the peace Jefferson County Kentucky
We the undersigned respectfully ask your Excellency to grant the Prayer of the above Petition

I take pleasure, in saying, that I believe the statements above, in reference to the character of Frank Slocum, having had him in Employ as Landscape Gardner, and would recommend that the Petition of E. S. Craig be granted
Louisville 8" Decr. 1863:
Dr P. Henderson

Knowing Mr Craig personally I am sure he has acted from the best motives. -- it will therefore be a hardship to compel payment
J. B. Kinkead
We think Mr. Craigs petition ought to be granted.
Gov Bramlett,

I have known Mr Craig for a long time and bear willing testamony, to his being a gentleman of high character, and without being personally acquainted with the facts, have no doubt they are fairly & correctly stated by him- and hope you may grant his request, and relieve him from the penalty of these bonds.

Respectfully.
J G Barret

Jefferson Cir Ct
vs
Remit all except fees & costs
Tho E Bramlette

E. S. Craig
2
Forfeiture of
$400 19th Oct/ 63
remitted 22d Dec 1863
